questions.text: Which of the following statements are false about lepromatous leprosy?

choices.text: The longest peripheral sensory nerves are affected first
Radiographic changes show cysts and osteoporosis
Sensation of palms and soles is lost early in the disease
bilaterally symmetrical distribution of skin lesions can occur anywhere apart from hairy scalp, axillae, groins and perineum

questions.solution:
In lepromatous leprosy sensation of palms and soles is retained until late in the disease. The longest peripheral sensory nerves are affected first, causing numbness and anesthesia on the dorsal surfaces of hands and feet, and later on extensor surfaces of arms and legs, and finally over the trunk.

Radiographs may show osteoporosis in the phalanges, small osteolytic cysts and often hairline or compression fractures.
Regions of skin with a higher temperature like hairy scalp, axillae, groins, and perineum do not typically show lesions of Lepromatous leprosy.

questions.text: A 48-year old man presented with the following skin lesion. It was noted that the lesions got aggravated after he was started on a beta-blocker. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of psoriasis with the image showing a psoriatic plaque, with a silvery center surrounded by a reddish border.

Plaque/ discoid psoriasis, also known as psoriasis vulgaris accounts for almost 90% of all psoriasis cases. It presents as a papulosquamous rash, with reddish edematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales, which are well-demarcated from unaffected skin with sharply delineated edges. Plaques may be encircled by a clear peripheral zone called the halo or ring of Woronoff. The scalp is one of the most common and first affected areas in plaque psoriasis, while other affected areas include elbows, knees, and back.

It can also be classified based on the site involved:

Plaque psoriasis (most common): sharply demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales, commonly present on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, etc.).


Guttate psoriasis: small scattered erythematous papules with silvery scales; often triggered by infections.


Erythrodermic psoriasis: confluent plaques affecting nearly all of the skin but often sparing the central face, with electrolyte and thermoregulation abnormalities.

Pustular psoriasis: presence of superficial pustules; generalized, annular, palmar-plantar, localized, and exanthemic variants are described.

Scalp psoriasis: well-demarcated plaques on the retro auricular areas and posterior upper neck.

Flexural/ inverse psoriasis: plaques affecting intertriginous folds, scaling may be less prominent.

Napkin psoriasis: may be seen in napkin (diaper) area in newborns.

Nail psoriasis: pits, splinter hemorrhages, oil drop sign (translucent yellow discoloration of the nail caused by parakeratosis of the nail bed), salmon patches, and leukonychia are common on the nail plate.

questions.text: Acne is not a diagnostic criteria in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
SACRAL syndrome is not characterised by Acne. It is a congenital condition characterized by Spinal dysraphism, Anogenital, Cutaneous, Renal and urologic anomalies, associated with an Angioma of Lumbosacral localization.  

SAPHO is an acronym for the combination of Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, Hyperostosis, and Osteitis.  

PASH is Pyoderma gangrenosum, Acne, and Suppurative Hidradenitis.  

PAPA syndrome is an acronym for Pyogenic Arthritis, Pyoderma gangrenosum and Acne.

questions.text: What differentiates malignancy associated Sweet syndrome from Idiopathic Sweet syndrome?
questions.solution:
Patients with malignancy‐associated Sweet syndrome differ from idiopathic Sweet syndrome in often having abnormal platelet counts and anemia. 

The skin lesions in malignancy‐associated Sweet syndrome are more likely to be vesicular, bullous or ulcerative.

Typical features of Sweet syndrome include:     

  • Non‐itchy, tender, erythematous plaques. 
  • Fever.    
  • Peripheral leucocytosis.  
  • Females are more frequently affected.

questions.text: Apple jelly nodules are seen in____
questions.solution: Initial lesion of lupus vulgaris is a plaque, composed of soft, reddish-brown papules, the appearance on diascopy being said to resemble apple jelly.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Wood lamp examination?

choices.text: Fungi growing on hair in vitro produces a characteristic fluorescence in UV light
The hair remains fluorescent after the fungus has ceased to be viable.
The fluorescent material can be extracted from hair in hot water.
Microsporum audouinii produces a brilliant green fluorescence.

questions.solution:
Fungi growing in culture or on hair in vitro do not fluoresce in a UV light.
The hair remains  fluorescent after the fungus has ceased to be viable, and the fluorescent material can be extracted from the hair in hot water or in a cold solution of sodium bromide.
Only dermatophytes capable of invading hair will induce  fluorescence, like Microsporum audouinni or M.canis.

questions.text: The following finding is seen in which clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Lichen planus (LP) shows whitish lines called Wickham striae (WS) in the papules of lichen planus and other dermatoses, typically in the oral mucosa. The macroscopic appearance shows hypergranulosis.

WS are of special significance in the diagnosis of erosive form of oral LP, as this form may undergo malignant transformation.

questions.text: Dercum’s disease affects which layer of skin?
questions.solution:
Dercum’s disease or Adiposis Dolorosa, affects the panniculus adiposus or true fatty layer of subcutaneous tissue.
It is a rare disease characterised by generalised pain in the adipose tissue and a number of fatty tumours.

The tumours are normally painful and found in multiples on the extremities.

questions.text: Buttonhole sign is can be seen all the following conditions, except?
questions.solution:
Buttonhole sign is not seen in bullous pemphigoid.  

In Von-Recklinghausen's disease (type 1 neurofibromatosis), neurofibromas can be invaginated with the tip of index finger back into the subcutis and again reappear after the release of pressure. (Buttonhole sign).

Other conditions where one can find this sign are anetoderma and dermatofibroma.

questions.text: A HIV-seropositive patient presents with a tender, unilateral fluctuant inguinal swelling and a non-indurated, painful ulcer on the glans penis. Which of following therapies should he be given?
questions.solution:
Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM in a single dose, is the first line of treatment for this HIV sero positive patient, who has findings which are indicative of Chancroid.

Azithromycin should be avoided in patients co-infected with HIV due to high treatment failure rate.

Single dose regimen are preferred as they have the advantage of ensuring compliance.

Treatment Ladder for Chancroid
First Line Azithromycin 1g orally single dose (Avoided in HIV positive patients)
or
Ceftriaxone 250mg IM single dose
Second Line Ciprofloxacin 500mg orally b.d x 3 days
or
Erythromycin 500mg oral q.i.d x 7 days

questions.text: For a patient with a suspected inherited connective tissue disorder, identify the sign demonstrated below.
questions.solution:
The picture depicts Gorlin’s sign, which is the ability of patients with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) to touch the tip of the nose with the tip of their tongue.

EDS is a connective tissue disorder occurring due to genetic defects involved in collagen synthesis and action. It is characterized by hyperextensibility of skin, hypermobile joints, easy bruising, and poor wound healing.

Other options:

Option A: Hertoghe’s sign is defined as the loss of lateral one-third of the eye-brows (superciliary madarosis) seen in leprosy, myxedema, atopic dermatitis, trichotillomania, ectodermal dysplasia, discoid lupus erythematosus, alopecia areata, syphilis, systemic sclerosis, HIV infection, and hypothyroidism.

Option B: Higoumenaki's sign refers to enlargement of the sternal end of the clavicle, frequently observed in patients with late congenital syphilis.

Option D: Gottron's sign refers to erythematous macules and patches overlying the elbows and/or knees seen in dermatomyositis.

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.

5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: Elastosis perforans serpiginosa is seen in all the following except?
questions.solution:
Elastosis perforans serpiginosa is not associated with SLE. It is a rare skin disorder in which abnormal elastic tissue fibre passes from the papillary dermis to the epidermis.

Types:

  • Idiopathic EPS: Unknown origin, possibly genetic
  • Reactive EPS: Associated with inherited disorders such as Down syndrome, Ehlers Danlos syndrome and Marfan syndrome, Osteogenesis Imperfecta and acrogeria
  • Drug-induced EPS: Affects 1% of people treated with D-penicillamine

questions.text: A patient with gingival fibromas, bone cysts and pitted dental enamel is said to have ______
questions.solution:
The patient with the given clinical features is said to have possible TSC.

 

Diagnostic criteria for the tuberous sclerosis complex:

 
Major features  
  • Facial angiofibromas or forehead plaque
  • Non‐traumatic ungual or periungual fibroma
  • Hypomelanotic macules (more than three)
  • Shagreen patch (connective tissue naevus)
  • Multiple retinal nodular hamartomas
  • Cortical tuber
  • Subependymal nodule
  • Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma
  • Cardiac rhabdomyoma, single or multiple
  • Lymphangiomyomatosis
  • Renal angiomyolipoma
Minor features 
  • Multiple randomly distributed pits in dental enamel
  • Hamartomatous rectal polyps
  • Bone cysts
  • Cerebral white matter migration lines
  • Gingival fibromas
  • Non‐renal hamartoma
  • Retinal achromic patch
  • Confetti’ skin lesions
  • Multiple renal cysts 
Diagnosis

Definite TSC: either two major features or one major feature with two minor features

Probable TSC: one major feature and one minor feature.

Possible TSC: either one major feature or two or more minor features

questions.text: On clinical examination of a patient complaining of intense itching, you notice the presence of the hang glider sign. This is caused by which of the following organisms_____?
questions.solution:
The hang glider sign refers to the dark triangular biting apparatus of Sarcoptes scabiei seen at the end of the subcorneal tunnel.

  • Demodex folliculorum is a follicle mite.
  • Ixodidae ticks are hard ticks.
  • Cimex hemipterus is a tropical bed bug.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Darier’s disease:

choices.text: It is due to mutations in intracellular calcium pumps
Terminal notches and white bands are seen in nails
Corticosteroids are first line of treatment
Papules are commonest on the seborrheic areas of the trunk, face, scalp margins, temples, ears, scalp, neck and flexures

questions.solution:
Emollients and topical antiseptics are the first lines of treatment, not corticosteroids. Darier’s disease is an autosomal dominant disease caused due to mutations in intracellular P-type calcium pumps.

It is characterized by chronic and recurrent focal and aggregated keratotic papules, generally of teenage or adult-onset, predominantly in seborrheic areas.

Treatment Ladder for Darrier's Disease (aka Keratosis Follicularis):

First Line

Emollients and topical antiseptics

Avoid excess heat or UVB
Second Line

Topical combination corticosteroids with antifungals/antibiotics

Topical retinoids

Oral antivirals, e.g. Acyclovir
Third Line

Topical 5‐ fluorouracil cream,

topical tacrolimus, topical tacalcitol,

Oral alitretinoin, Photodynamic therapy

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not associated with a pityriasis rosea like eruption?
questions.solution:
Oral contraceptives are not associated with a pityriasis rosea like eruption. They are associated with an erythema nodosum like eruption (and not pityriasis rosea like eruption).

Other drugs commonly causing erythema nodosum like eruption include:   

  • Hormonal replacement therapy
  • Sulphonamides    
  • Penicillin  

Pityriasis rosea like eruption is associated commonly with the following:  

  • Angiotensin‐converting enzyme inhibitors
  • NSAIDs     
  • Gold

questions.text: The earliest manifestation of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis is:
questions.solution:
The earliest manifestation of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc) is Raynaud phenomenon which can precede other manifestations by many years.

Note that Raynaud phenomenon is the earliest manifestation in the limited cutaneous variant of Systemic sclerosis (lcSSc /CREST syndrome) and not diffuse cutaneous SSc(dcSSc) in which Raynaud phenomenon may appear along with or much after the appearance of other cutaneous manifestations.

Pruritus, non-pitting edema and puffiness, pigmentation & de-pigmentation are generally early skin changes seen in both variants of Systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: Pseudo porphyria cutanea tarda is not characterized by

choices.text: Good prognosis following discontinuation of drug

questions.solution:
The classic features of hypertrichosis, hyperpigmentation, and sclerodermoid changes found with porphyria cutanea tarda are unusual with pseudoporphyria.

Pseudoporphyria can be induced by a wide range of medications, excessive UV-A exposure, and haemodialysis.
The prognosis is good for pseudoporphyria once the offending agent has been discontinued. If the serum/plasma porphyrin assay is negative, the patient does not have a true porphyria.

questions.text:
In Pemphigus Vulgaris, which of the following is true?
1: Anti desmoglein(anti-Dsg ) 1 antibodies predominate
2: There is marked blistering of the mucosa, with relative sparing of skin

choices.text: Both are correct and 1 is the reason for 2
Both are correct, but 1 is independent of 2

questions.solution:
In Pemphigus vulgaris, there is marked blistering of mucosa with relative sparing of skin.

In pemphigus vulgaris, Anti-Dsg 3 antibodies predominate. As, Dsg 3 is present in all the layers of mucosa, but is found only in the basal and immediate suprabasal layers of skin; the oral epithelium is primarily affected with relative sparing of skin remaining.

In the case of Pemphigus foliaceus, Anti- Dsg 1 antibodies predominate. Hence skin is primarily affected with sparing of oral mucosa.

questions.text: A recently weaned child presents with perioral vesicular plaques sparing the upper lip and diarrhea. What is he likely to be deficient in?
questions.solution:
This is the classical presentation of zinc deficiency leading to acrodermatitis enteropathica (Transient neonatal zinc deficiency) with diarrhea, alopecia, and a perioral and acral cutaneous eruption.  

The perioral eruption usually spares the upper lip, resulting in a ‘U' or ‘horseshoe‐shaped’ appearance. Risk factors include weaning from the breast, anorexia nervosa, alcoholism, vegetarianism, and inadequately supplemented total parenteral nutrition. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremor, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, etc.

Skin manifestations such as vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities and periorificial(perianal, perigenital, perioral) regions are commonly seen as shown below. Affected infants require long-term supplementation with zinc.

The deficiency of copper leads to Menkes kinky hair syndrome.

Deficiency of selenium leads to Keshan disease and Kashin–Beck disease.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions do not show pseudo-Pautrier's microabscesses on histopathology?
questions.solution:
Psoriasis shows Munro's microabscess (collection of neutrophils) in the stratum corneum of the epidermis due to the infiltration of neutrophils from the papillary dermis into the epidermal stratum corneum.  

 

Pautrier’s microabscesses are the hallmark of mycosis fungoides, the collections consist of atypical lymphocytes that have a cerebriform nucleus and scant cytoplasm.

Pseudo Pautrier’s microabscesses are described as spongiotic stimulants of Pautrier's microabscesses and consist of Langerhans cells, histiocytes, stellate keratinocytes, and rare lymphocytes. They are also seen in mycosis fungoides. 

Carbamazepine induced skin lesions resemble and show skin biopsy features of MF. Condition undergoes remission after drug discontinuation. Spongiotic and lichenoid dermatitis also show pseudo Pautrier's microabscesses.

questions.text: The ugly duckling sign is seen in patients with ____________
questions.solution:
The ugly duckling sign/concept is that nevi in the same individual tend to resemble one another morphologically and naevus which does not fit into any of the few dominant patterns of naevi of a given individual deserves attention.  Malignant melanoma often deviates from this naevus pattern.  

It is considered more discriminatory between malignant melanoma and other nevi than the ABCDE criteria.

The following four principles are usually applied in the diagnosis of Melanoma: 

  • Analytical examination - this involves the ABCDE algorithm used for diagnosis. 
  • Pattern recognition - the idea behind this principle is those who see more melanomas will more easily recognize a new one. 
  • Comparative analysis - Ugly duckling sign forms part of intraindividual comparative analysis, with a comparison between patterns of naevi an individual usually possess and variation from this usual pattern. 
  • Dynamic analysis- Naevi grow and change over the years but melanomas often evolve rapidly. This evolutionary comparison is useful in making the distinction between a naevus and melanoma.

questions.text: Walzel sign is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This clinical sign refers to livedoreticularis seen in association with acute and chronic pancreatitis.  

Other signs seen in patients with pancreatitis are Grey Turner's sign, Cullen's sign, and Trousseau's sign.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the image given below.
questions.solution:
The above image with fish-like scales is suggestive of ichthyosis. It is a family of genetic disorders characterized by the presence of excessive amounts of dry thickened scaly skin.  

The commonest form of ichthyosis vulgaris is due to a genetic defect in the gene FLG coding for filaggrin protein. Ichthyosis usually develops during the first months of life. 

The patients present with light grey scales mainly on the extensor surfaces of the extremities and the trunk. The scaling may disappear or reduce in the summer and when there is increased humidity. They usually have accentuated palmar creases.

The condition is managed with ointments like glycerol-containing creams that hydrate the stratum corneum.

Other options:

Option A: Acrodermatitis enteropathica is caused by a defect in the absorption of zinc. It presents as eczematous plaques that are usually periorificial on the face or the anogenital area. They may become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with crusting at the edges. It is shown below.

 

Option C: Atopic dermatitis in children classically have patches and plaques on antecubital and popliteal fossae. Adults have chronic lichenified lesions mainly on the hands. It is associated with itching. It is shown below.

Option D: Kaposi sarcoma: Skin lesions of Kaposi sarcoma are dark blue to purple and may partially blanch when swollen. They are usually multifocal and may fuse to form plaques and tumors. It is seen below.

Related Pearl: Types of scales associated with dermatological conditions

Types of Scales and Associated Diseases

Type of Scale

Associated Disease

It is a fine, peripherally attached, and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion. It is seen in pityriasis rosea.

They are characteristic of processes involving parakeratosis, especially psoriasis. The silvery color is due to the reflection of light at several air–keratin interfaces.

questions.text: Which of the following genes is not associated with an increased risk of melanoma?
questions.solution:
SLC45A2 (MATP) and TYRP1 are not associated with increased risk of melanoma but instead appear to be protective against melanoma.

The cyclin‐dependent kinase (CDKN2A) inhibitor 2A gene is the best established high‐risk locus for melanoma susceptibility. It encodes for p16/Ink4a and p14/Arf by affecting the Rb and p53 cancer pathways.

The CDK4 gene encodes the kinase targeted by p16/Ink4a. Any mutation of this gene abolishes the binding domain and is tumourigenesis.

The melanocortin‐1 receptor (MC1R) gene is considered as a moderate‐risk gene for melanoma.

questions.text: Psuedo isomorphic phenomenon can be seen in a patient with ________________
questions.solution:
Pseudo-isomorphic/pseudo-Koebner phenomenon can be seen in patients with warts as the new lesions occur due to the seeding of infection.

Koebner phenomenon or true Koebnerisation is typically seen in psoriasis, vitiligo, and lichen planus.

Koebner/isomorphic phenomenon refers to the appearance of new skin lesions on healthy skin at the site of cutaneous injury, in the presence of a pre-existing dermatosis. They are typically linear, as they follow the route of the injury.

Koebner phenomenon is diagnosed clinically using the following characteristics:

  • Linear lesions developing at the site of cutaneous injury on a previously healthy skin
  • Lesions have the same clinical and histological features as the underlying dermatosis
  • Lesions are not due to seeding of an infectious agent, allergic reaction or skin breakdown

The exact cause of such a response is unclear. Theories involving T-cell mediated response, involvement of dermis, and microvasculature are considered. Various triggers for Koebner phenomenon have been identified:

  • Trauma: Insect and animal bites, burns including thermal and electric, excoriation, friction, shaving, lacerations, cryotherapy, pressure sores, and orthotics
  • Chemical irritation: Tattoo associated skin reaction, BCG vaccination, tuberculin skin test, hair dye allergy
  • Diseases: Urticaria, inflammatory dermatoses
  • Others: Phototherapy, sunburn, withdrawal of methotrexate therapy

Other features of Koebner phenomenon include:

  • Graded response to trauma: Intensity of response to trauma is unique to each patient and the underlying disease.
    • No Koebner response to injury
    • Abortive Koebner response: Lesions appear, but spontaneously vanish after a few weeks
    • Minimal Koebner response: Lesions develop at the site of trauma
    • Maximal Koebner response: Wide spread lesions develop across the entire site of trauma
  • All or nothing response: Patients who develop Koebner phenomenon in response to one type of injury, may develop a similar response due to other types of injuries as well. In case, a patient does not exhibit Koebner phenomenon to one type of injury, it is unlikely that it is exhibited after any other type of injury.
  • Time taken to develop the skin lesions is unique to the patient and the specific dermatosis. It may vary from 3 days to 2 years, normally taking around 10-20 days.

Koebner phenomenon can be classified into:

  • True Koebnerisation: New skin lesions seen with the clinical features mentioned above, as seen in vitiligo, psoriasis and lichen planus.  
  • Pseudo-Koebnerisation: Appearance of similar skin lesions at the site of injury in infective lesions like plane warts and molluscum contagiosum, due to the spread of the infective agent (virus) to the new site by seeding, especially due to scratching.

The image below shows Koebner phenomenon seen in a psoriatic patient at the site of trauma.

Koebner phenomenon is also seen in other diseases like:

  • Erythema multiforme
  • Lichen nidatus
  • Necrobiosis lipodica
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Hailey-Hailey disease
  • Darier disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Pityriasis rubra pilaris

Other phenomena associated with cutaneous trauma are:

  • Reverse Koebner phenomenon: Disappearance of skin lesions after trauma to the area, which is seen in psoriasis after dermabrasion or surgery.
  • Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon: Spontaneous repigmentation is seen in distant patches after autologous skin graft surgery in vitiligo.
  • Wolf's isotopic response/isotopic phenomenon: Emergence of new dermatosis at the site of a previous unrelated dermatosis as seen in granuloma annulare developing at the site of herpes zoster and psoriasis developing at the site of contact dermatitis.
  • Pathergy: Occurance of non-specific papules and pustules secondary to heavy neutrophilic infiltrates after an injection or venipuncture, as seen in pyoderma gangrenosum and Behçet disease.
  • Renbök/inverse Koebner phenomenon: Disappearance of an existing skin condition after the onset of a new dermatosis at the same site, as seen in retention of hair follicles on the psoriatic plaques on the scalp while hair loss was present in unaffected areas of alopecia areata.

questions.text: Antibody against which of the following structures is likely to be seen in a patient with bullous systemic lupus erythematosus
questions.solution:
Antibody against type VII collagen is seen in a patient with bullous systemic lupus erythematosus as it is the target antigen.

The most common cutaneous manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus is photosensitivity. The cutaneous manifestations in SLE are:

  1. Photosensitivity
  2. Raynaud's phenomenon 
  3. Malar rash
  4. Chronic urticaria >36 hrs
  5. Non-scarring alopecia 
  6. Mouth ulceration

questions.text: All the following statements are false about Incontinentia pigmenti except?

choices.text: Life expectancy is usually lowered with Stage 4 lesions
Majority of patients are neurologically affected

questions.solution:
Incontinentia pigmenti (IP) is a rare X‐linked dominant multisystemic ectodermal dysplasia that is usually lethal in males, not females. 

Cutaneous Manifestations:

  • A typical perinatal presentation comprises an erythematous vesicular rash following the Blaschko’s lines and denotes Stage 1.
  • Stage II shows a verrucous lesion & Stage III shows hyperpigmented streaks and whorls along Blaschko’s lines.
  • In stage IV, seen during adolescence, pale, hair-less, atrophic linear streaks or patches are seen, mostly on the lower extremities.

Extracutaneous abnormalities:

  • Dental Abnormalities
  • Ophthalmological abnormalities with retinal neovascularization.
  • CNS abnormalities include microcephaly, seizures and neurocognitive and motor impairments. But the majority (>60%) of patients are neurologically normal

 There may be associated onychodystrophy and alopecia

Management:

  • No specific treatment is available for IP. Symptomatic Management is done.
  • Life expectancy is usually normal.

questions.text: Gluten-free diet is a treatment modality in_____.
questions.solution:
A gluten‐free diet is the cornerstone of long‐term dermatitis herpetiformis management. This also treats the associated gluten sensitive enteropathy (GSE) and may decrease the long‐term risk of lymphoma.  

Gluten‐free diet has a slow response, so most patients require pharmacological intervention.

Dapsone and related sulphonamide drugs have proven highly effective, suppressing pruritus within days of treatment

questions.text: A 15 year old boy who presents with hyperkeratotic lesions over pressure points on his palms and soles and oral leukoplakia over the gums is worried about other conditions he might have. What should he be screened for?
questions.solution:
He should be screened for Oesophageal carcinoma, as it frequently develops in patients with Howel Evans syndrome.

It is an autosomal dominantly inherited focal palmoplantar keratoderma (tylosis) with the eventual development of oesophageal carcinoma and oral leukoplakia.

questions.text: A chronic asthmatic patient who is on inhaled steroids presents with a history of a burning sensation on eating spicy food and the following findings are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of erythematous candidiasis.

Erythematous (atrophic) candidiasis appears as a red, raw-looking lesion. It may or may not be related to pseudo membranes. On the tongue, there is a loss of the lingual papillae, leaving a smooth area. It can occur after long term corticosteroids or antibiotics usage or those with HIV. Other names for this condition include Acute atrophic oral candidiasis and Antibiotic sore tongue.

Chronic erythematous candidiasis is usually associated with denture wearing.

Candidiasis of the oral mucosal membranes is of the following types:

Type of Candidiasis Description 

Acute pseudomembranous candidiasis /

Oral thrush / 

Chronic pseudomembranous candidiasis 

Sharply defined patch of creamy, crumbly, curd‐like, white pseudomembrane

Has an underlying erythematous base
Acute erythematous candidiasis 

Denuded, atrophic, erythematous mucous membranes

Most common- dorsum of
the tongue 

Chronic erythematous candidiasis /

Chronic atrophic candidiasis / 

Denture stomatitis

Affected areas show a variable bright red or dusky erythema

Fairly sharply defined at the margin of the denture

Chronic plaque‐like candidiasis / 

Chronic hyperplastic candidiasis /

Candida leukoplakia

Very persistent, firm, irregular, white plaques occur in the mouth

Commonly on the cheek or tongue 
Chronic nodular candidiasis Tongue has a cobbled appearance
Angular cheilitis/Angular stomatitis/ Perlèche Soreness at the angles of the mouth extending outwards in the
folds of the facial skin

Other options:

Burning mouth syndrome (BMS) is a burning sensation in the mouth with no underlying dental or medical cause where no related signs of disease are found in the mouth.

Geographic tongue, though consistent with the clinical image is not the best fit considering the clinical history. It is usually asymptomatic but can be occasionally associated with a sore tongue. It usually is associated with a history of being not constant in size, shape, or location.

Oral lichen planus is associated with Wickham striae in the oral cavity. They are fine white lines in a lacy or fern-like pattern that cross the plaques in lichen planus.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cutaneous manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution:
The most common cutaneous manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus is photosensitivity.

In decreasing order, the cutaneous manifestations in SLE are:

  1. Photosensitivity
  2. Raynaud's phenomenon 
  3. Malar rash
  4. Chronic urticaria >36 hrs
  5. Non-scarring alopecia 
  6. Mouth ulceration

questions.text: The image shows an investigative modality of nail folds. This along with ANA testing helps in the early diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
The given image shows nail-fold capillaroscopy findings. The image shows giant capillaries, hemorrhages, and reducing capillary density suggesting an active pattern in systemic sclerosis.

The most important tests for systemic sclerosis are ANA reactivity and nail fold capillaroscopy. Investigations to exclude or confirm other autoimmune rheumatic diseases including arthritis or other forms of connective tissue disease are also done. 

Nail-fold capillaroscopy is a non-invasive, easy, and safe diagnostic technique designed to evaluate the general architecture of capillary rows and fine details of small vessels of the microcirculation in the nail fold.

The most important indications for performing capillaroscopy include differential diagnosis of primary and secondary Raynaud's phenomenon, as well as the assessment of scleroderma spectrum disorders.

In systemic sclerosis, capillary abnormalities appear and evolve in a clearly defined sequence called the scleroderma pattern, which correlates with internal organ involvement.

Nail fold capillaroscopy is also listed as a systemic sclerosis classification criterion recognized by the European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR).

questions.text: In which of the following patients would you expect to see a positive Dory flop sign?

choices.text: A young woman with a painless beefy red granulomatous ulcer on her vulva
A middle-aged man with an painless indurated lesion on his penis
A circumcised teenager with multiple painful vesicles over his penis
A lady with a painless indurated ulcer over her labia majora

questions.solution:
The Dory flop sign is described in an uncircumcised male with an indurated lesion of primary syphilis on the underside of the coronal sulcus. Here, prepucial retraction causes the foreskin to flip suddenly. Hence it would only be seen in the middle-aged man with the indurated lesion on his penis. 

The Dory flop sign can help distinguish chancres from other nonindurated causes of genital ulcer disease, such as Herpes simplex virus infection and chancroid.

It is named after the movement of a dory, a small wooden fishing boat, which flips suddenly when overturned.  

Option A: This young woman has granuloma inguinale, which is a non-indurated lesion.

Option C: This circumcised teenager has herpes genitalis.

Option D: Though this lady has an indurated lesion (chancre), the dory flop sign can be demonstrated only in uncircumcised males.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was referred to a urologist for the following finding. Which of the following would not have caused this?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown in the above image depicts a penis that is twisted along its long axis, which is called saxophone penis. It is a late complication of lymphogranuloma venereum, penile tuberculosis, and primary lymphedema. It does not occur in donovanosis. 

It occurs as a complication of long-standing inflammation, which causes fibrosis of lymphatics and connective tissue. The dorsal surface of the penis has a poor blood supply compared to the ventral surface and undergoes more fibrosis. This leads to a dorsal bend of the penis. 

Gonococcal urethritis can lead to periurethral abscesses, which result in urethral strictures. In males, this may cause a saxophone penis deformity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the Amsel criteria?
questions.solution:
Acidic pH is not a feature of the Amsel criteria, which are used for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis.

3 out of 4 of the following criteria are needed for a positive diagnosis:

  1. Homogeneous, thin, grayish-white discharge that smoothly coats the vaginal walls.
  2. Vaginal pH > 4.5.
  3. Positive whiff-amine test - Fishy odor when a drop of 10% KOH is added to vaginal discharge.
  4. Clue cells on saline wet mount: Vaginal epithelial cells studded with adherent coccobacilli at the edge of the cell.

Bacterial vaginosis is caused by a reduction in lactobacilli, and an increase in anaerobic organisms such as Gardnerella vaginalis, Mycoplasma hominis and Prevotella species.

Nugent scoring system is highly sensitive and is considered the gold standard for bacterial vaginosis. It is calculated using Gram-stained smear findings and observing the number of lactobacilli and morphology of anaerobes. High scores of  7–10 indicate bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: What would be the standard therapy for a patient with the following condition?
questions.solution:
Hydroxychloroquine (antimalarial) is the first-line systemic agent for discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE). The lesions seen in the image are characteristic of DLE.

The primary lesion is an erythematous papule. As it progresses pigmentary changes develop, with hypopigmentation in the central, or inactive area, and hyperpigmentation at the active border.  

Other options:

  • Thalidomide is considered in patients who are resistant to antimalarials. 
  • Topical and intralesional corticosteroids are a part of the standard therapy, but systemic steroids are avoided since dose and duration may result in a lot of side effects. 
  • Topical retinoids are also considered helpful, but they are not the initial therapy.

questions.text: The microscopic examination of a sample obtained from a genital ulcer is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Donovan bodies, which points to a diagnosis of granuloma inguinale.

Donovan bodies refer to the Gram-negative rod-shaped or oval organisms that show bipolar staining or safety‐pin appearance, present intracellularly in the cytoplasm of large mononuclear cells.

Option B: Neisseria gonorrhoeae appears on microscopy as Gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes as seen below.

Option C: Microscopy of chancroid lesions shows H. ducreyi in a sheet-like or school of fish railroad pattern as seen below.

Option D: In LGV, an increased number of polymorphonuclear leukocytes are noted on microscopy.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding morphea.

choices.text: Plaque morphea is the most common form
Absence of sclerodactyly and nail fold capillary changes
Antitopoisomerase and anticentromere are usually positive
Encoup de Sabre is linear morphea presenting as scarring alopecia

questions.solution:
Autoantibodies such as ANA, anti-histone, and anti‐ssDNA may be present in morphea, but the systemic sclerosis specific autoantibodies such as anti-topoisomerase, anti-centromere and anti‐RNA polymerase are rarely found.

Morphoea, a term used in preference to ‘localized scleroderma’, encompasses a group of related conditions characterized by varying degrees of sclerosis, fibrosis, and atrophy in the skin and subcutaneous tissues.

It is distinguished from systemic sclerosis by the absence of sclerodactyly and nail-fold capillary changes.

Overall, plaque morphea is the commonest subtype.

Morphoea en coup de sabre: Blaschkoid linear induration affecting the face and scalp, may involve underlying muscle, bone, eye, and the brain.

questions.text: A patient with an outbreak of cold sores 2 days ago now presents with non-pruritic lesions on his elbow, as seen below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of cold sores, a herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, followed by the appearance of pathognomic target lesions, as seen in the image, is suggestive of erythema multiforme.

Erythema multiforme (EM) is an acute, self-limited, skin condition that is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction associated with certain infections, medications, and other triggers. Precipitating factors commonly include HSV strains 1 and 2, EBV, and drugs like sulfa drugs. This is consistent with the patient history of having had cold sores.

It presents as a localized eruption of the skin with minimal or no mucosal involvement. The papules then evolve into pathognomonic target or iris lesions that appear within a 72-hour period and begin on the extremities. Lesions remain in a fixed location for at least 7 days and then begin to heal.  

Other options:

Option A: Viral exanthem is an eruptive skin rash that is often related to a viral infection. It can have various types of rash based on the virus associated.

Option B: Acute exanthematous pustulosis is associated with drug reaction and presents as small non-follicular pustules on an erythematous base that undergo spontaneous resolution.

Option D: Drug eruptions are cutaneous manifestations that are often related to a drug used. It can have various types of rash based on the drug used.

Related Pearl: Erythema multiforme vs. Stevens-Johnson syndrome/Toxic epidermal necrolysis

 

  Erythema multiforme major Stevens-Johnsons Syndrome Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (Lyell syndrome)
% Body Surface-area

<10%

 <10% >30%
Causes Herpes simplex> Mycoplasma infection Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol
Associated Symptoms Less fever and other constitutional symptoms Fever, malaise and headache Fever, malaise and headache
Mucosal Lesions Milder mucosal lesions Severe mucosal involvement Severe mucosal involvement
Lesions Erythematous papules, Target lesions, raised atypical target lesions, occasional bullous lesions

Vesicles on erythematous base, erosions, purpuric macules, Flat atypical target lesions

Nikolsky Sign Positive

Diffuse, generalized epidermal detachment

TEN with spots - with widespread purpuric macules and flat atypical target lesions

TEN without spots- loss of large epidermal sheets without purpuric macules or target lesions

 Nikolsky Sign Positive
Distribution Acral – distal extremities Variable distribution Extensive distribution
Histo-pathology Interface dermatitis – Basal cell vacuolization, apoptotic bodies and inflammatory cells at Dermo-epidermal junction Dermo-epidermal separation, Intense inflammatory cell infiltrates in dermis, some areas of epidermal detachment  Epidermal necrosis, Dermo-epidermal separation, minimal dermal inflammatory cell infiltrate, large areas of epidermal detachment.
Recurrence Common, related to Herpes infections Uncommon, drug-related Uncommon, drug-related
Mortality Rare – recovery in 1 to 4 weeks Elevated mortality Highest mortality

 

Note: Overlap SJS-TEN: There is detachment of 10–30% body surface area, plus widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets.

Erythema Multiforme is regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs.

Related Pearl: Glossary of important skin lesions

Glossary of Important Skin Lesions

Lesion

Description

Alopecia

Absence of hair from a normally hairy area

Aphtha

A small ulcer of the mucosa

Atrophy

Loss of tissue from one or more of the epidermis, dermis or subcutaneous tissues

Burrow

A small tunnel in the skin that houses a parasite, such as the scabies acarus

Callus

A localized hyperplasia of the stratum corneum

Cellulitis

An inflammation of cellular tissue, particularly purulent inflammation of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

Comedo

A plug of keratin and sebum in a dilated pilosebaceous orifice

Crusts (scabs)

Crusts consist of dried serum and other exudates

Cyst

Any closed cavity or sac (normal or abnormal) with an epithelial, endothelial or membranous lining and containing fluid or semi‐solid material

Ecchymosis

A macular area of hemorrhage more than 1 cm (bruise) in diameter

Erosion

A loss of epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

Erythema

Redness of the skin produced by vascular congestion or increased perfusion

Excoriation

Loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching

Exfoliation

The splitting off of the epidermal keratin in scales or sheets

Fibrosis

The formation of excessive fibrous tissue

Fissure

Any linear gap or slit in the skin surface

Fistula

An abnormal passage from a deep structure, such as a hollow viscus, to the skin surface or between two structures

Gangrene

Death of tissue, usually due to loss of blood supply

Guttate lesions

Small round or oval lesions distributed as a ‘shower’ of droplets. Usually applied to a form of psoriasis

Hematoma

A localized tumor‐like collection of blood

Keratoderma

A horny thickening of the skin

Lichenification

Thickening of the epidermis (and to some extent also of the dermis) in response to prolonged rubbing

Macule

A flat circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion that differs in color from the surrounding skin. It can be of any color or shape. A macule is <1 cm in diameter, larger lesions are a patch.

Maculopapular

Rash consisting of both macules and papules

Milium

A tiny white cyst containing lamellated keratin

Nodule*

A solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is >0.5 cm in diameter.

Papule

An elevated solid lesion that is <1 cm in diameter.

Petechia

A punctate hemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter.

Plaque

An elevated circumscribed lesion >1 cm diameter; its surface is usually flat. Plaques may form from coalesced papules.

Poikiloderma

The association of cutaneous pigmentation, and telangiectasia.

Pustule

A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. 

Pyoderma

Any purulent skin disease

Scale

Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated of stratum corneum.

Scar

Replacement by fibrous tissue of another tissue that has been destroyed by injury or disease

An atrophic scar is thin and wrinkled.

A hypertrophic scar is elevated, with excessive growth of fibrous tissue.

Sclerosis

Diffuse or circumscribed induration of the subcutaneous tissues. It may also involve the dermis, when the overlying epidermis may be atrophic. It is characteristically seen in scleroderma.

Sinus

A cavity or track with a blind ending

Target lesions

These are <3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of edema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Tumor

Literally a swelling; the term is used to imply enlargement of the tissues by normal or pathological material, or cells that form a mass. 

Ulcer (of skin)

A loss of dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues
Vesicles and Bullae

 A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation <1 cm in diameter that contains fluid

Bullae are >1 cm in diameter
Wheal  A transient elevation of the skin due to dermal and hypodermal, often pale centrally with an erythematous rim; it is the characteristic lesion of urticaria.

 *While Rook's textbook of Dermatology,9th edition mention nodule as >0.5 cm. Some authors define nodules as >1 cm.

questions.text: The most common skin- related complaint reported in patients with HIV is _________.
questions.solution:
In the post-antiretroviral era, idiopathic pruritus has become the most common skin-related disease manifestation reported in patients with HIV.

The other common skin manifestations are:

  • Xerosis (23%) and icythyosis
  • Nodular prurigo
  • Folliculitis
  • Eosinophilic folliculitis
  • Pruritic papular eruption
  • Seborrhoeic dermatitis (9%)
  • Granuloma annulare
  • Drug eruptions
  • Herpes simplex
  • Herpes zoster
  • Viral warts
  • Mollusca
  • Oral and vaginal candidosis
  • Tinea (including onychomycosis)

questions.text: A 59-year-old lady, a known diabetic for the past 10 years, presents with rashes over shin as shown in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an erythematous rash with ulceration and healing over the shin. This clinical presentation in a diabetic patient is indicative of necrobiosis lipoidica.

Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is a rare chronic and granulomatous skin disorder that affects only 0.3% of diabetic patients. The average age of onset is 30 years, with females being affected more commonly. Its postulated etiology is microangiopathy.

Most rashes are located on the legs, especially above the tibiae. It may present as red papules that enlarge to form patches or plaques with an atrophic yellowish-brown and slightly depressed center.The lesions may resolve spontaneously or become persistent chronic lesions, that can ulcerate.

Option A: Granuloma annular is most commonly found in children and females <30 years. It manifests as groups of 1-2mm papules that range from skin colored to violaceous, in an annular arrangement over distal extremities. There is no confirmed association with diabetes.

Option C: Reactive perforating collagenosis (folliculitis) has been reported in patients with diabetes. It is attributed to collagen glycation.

Option D: Rubeosis is a peculiar rosy reddening of the face, and sometimes hands and feet. In longstanding diabetes, it is attributed to microangiopathy or decreased vascular tone.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions causes bamboo hair as seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
Bamboo hair is seen in Netherton syndrome.

It presents with atopy, recurrent skin infection, and an increased risk of skin cancer. It has two characteristic features, namely:

  • Ichthyosis linearis circumflexa - a rare form of ichthyosis with scaling and plaques.
  • Trichorrhexis invaginata or bamboo hair - characterized by invagination of the distal hair shaft into the proximal portion. It is also called golf-tee or ball and socket appearance as seen below.

Option A: Trichorrhexis nodosa is associated with trauma to the hair shaft and arginosuccinic aciduria. It causes node formation and fractures which results in the thrust paintbrush appearance seen below as if two paintbrushes are rubbing against each other.

Option C: Menkes kinky hair syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder of copper metabolism. It is associated with pili torti or twisted hairs, seen in the first image, and monilethrix or beaded hair, seen in the second image.

Option D: Uncombable hair syndrome produces a characteristic triangular cross-section of hair and longitudinal groove along one side which contributes to its hair stiffness.

questions.text: In a 6-year-old boy who presented with black stools, the following finding was noted. Endoscopy showed multiple polyps in the GI tract. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Patients need to undergo lifelong screening
Malignant transformation of polyps is common
Due to mutation of STK11 gene

questions.solution:
The presence of multiple polyps in the GI tract along with lentigines on the lips is suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers-Touraine syndrome. Malignant transformation of hamartomatous polyps is rare.

It is an autosomal dominant disease. It is due to the mutation of the serine/threonine kinase gene (STK11).

Typical cutaneous features include lentigines of the lips (early feature). Associated melanocytic macules of buccal mucosa and digits are common. Hamartomatous polyps are present mainly in the jejunum but can occur throughout the GI tract.

Patients require lifelong screening as they are at high risk for carcinomas of the breast, ovary, colon, and stomach.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

questions.text: All of the following are causes of erythroderma except  _______
questions.solution:
Pityriasis rosea is not a cause of erythroderma.

The most common causes of erythroderma in decreasing order of frequency are:

  • Eczema of various subtypes including seborrheic dermatitis
  • Psoriasis 
  • Lymphoma and leukemia
  • Drugs - phenylbutazone, phenytoin, carbamazepine, gold salts, lithium, cimetidine
  • Hereditary disorders - ichthyosiform erythroderma, pityriasis rubra pilaris
  • Pemphigus foliaceus
  • Other skin diseases - lichen planus, dermatophytosis, crusted scabies, dermatomyositis

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is rushed to the casualty with sudden-onset breathing difficulty. History reveals that her father also suffers from similar episodes. Examination findings are as follows. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Type II of this condition is most common
The enzyme involved is C1 INH
There is loss of inhibition of Hageman factor
Associated with  C4 and C2 deficiency

questions.solution:
The image shows subcutaneous and submucosal edema of the face and lips without wheals. Along with the history, a diagnosis of hereditary angioedema (HAE) is most likely. Type I HAE is the most common form (85%).

There are three types of hereditary angioedema (HAE):

  • Type 1 (85%): C1INH deficiency 
  • Type 2 (15%): Dysfunction of C1-INH, but normal levels
  • Type 3 (rare) :  Normal C1-INH levels and function

HAE occurs due to a mutation in the SERPING1 gene, which codes for the C1 esterase inhibitor (C1INH). It is also called angioneurotic edema or Quincke's disease.

C1INH enzyme normally inhibits the following:

  • Complement system
  • Kallikrein system
  • Factor XII or Hageman factor

In HAE, loss of C1INH activity leads to loss of inhibition of these above processes. This leads to decreased C4 and C2 levels and bradykinin accumulation.

questions.text: A patient presented with a pruritic lesion on his face. Microbiological examination of swabs taken from the lesion showed Gram-positive cocci arranged in pairs and chains. Which of the following is not a possible complication of his condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of streptococcal impetigo. Rheumatic fever is a complication of streptococcal pharyngitis, not impetigo.

The complications of streptococcal impetigo include: 

  • Scarlet fever
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
  • Cellulitis 

Infective complications are uncommon in the absence of systemic disease or malnutrition.

questions.text: A 35-year-old construction worker presented with a non-pruritic lesion for 4 weeks. KOH mount of the epidermal scrapings showed brown, branched, closely septate hyphae and elongated budding cells. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and image are suggestive of tinea nigra (pityriasis nigra). It is a rare superficial fungal infection caused by Hortaea werneckii. 

The infection occurs by direct inoculation through the skin. It causes deeply pigmented, macular, non-scaly patches commonly on palms. 

First-line treatment is topical azole creams such as econazole and ketoconazole.

The image below shows a microscopic image of tinea nigra, with pigmented filaments with conidia. 

Option B: Malassezia globosa causes tinea versicolor.

Option C: Fusarium causes mycotoxicosis.

Option D: Piedraia hortae causes black piedra.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes hard black nodules over scalp hair?
questions.solution:
The hard black nodules over the scalp hair are suggestive of black piedra. It is a fungal infection of the hair shafts caused by Piedraia hortae.

The fungus forms hard, dark, gritty, and superficial nodules on the hair shafts. As the fungus grows into the hair shaft, the hair may fracture easily. It produces sexual spores in its parasitic phase.

Treatment:

  • Shaving or cutting hair (prevents recurrence also)
  • Benzoic acid ointment is used.  

Option B: Trichosporon beigelli causes white piedra or trichosporosis nodosa.

Option C: Corynebacterium tenuis causes trichomycosis axillaris.

Option D: Trichophyton tonsurans causes mainly tinea capitis.

The images below show black piedra infected hair mounted in 30% KOH and the appearance of hair strands, respectively. The dark nodules are formed of dematiaceous hyphae cemented together to form a hard mass.

 

The images given below show white piedra. Superficial, soft, white, grey, or brown nodules can be seen.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the types of hair.

choices.text: Melanin is absent in vellus hair
Vellus hair depth extends to the subcutis
The medulla is thicker in terminal hairs

questions.solution:
Vellus hair extends to the dermis and not the subcutis.

Lanugo refers to the fine, soft, unmedullated and usually unpigmented hair of the prenatal period. It is normally shed in utero in the eighth to ninth months of gestation.

Postnatal hair is of two kinds: vellus and terminal.
